metadata.titleEn: Jurassic granite data set of Sulu orogenic belt
metadata.description: The data include sampling information, age, elements, isotopes, hand specimen photos, micrographs, geochemical characteristics and diagenetic model maps of Jurassic granites in Sulu orogenic belt. X-ray fluorescence spectrometry (XRF) was used to determine the major elements with an accuracy of less than 2%, and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) was used to determine the trace elements with an accuracy of less than 5%. The zircon U-Pb isotopic age was determined by SIMS. The data have been published in Journal of petroleum, an international well-known petrological journal, which has important implications for the post collisional evolution of the Sulu orogenic belt.
metadata.instructions:
File naming: sampling information, age, element, isotope data and image annotation are stored in Excel file, and hand specimen photos, micrographs, geochemical characteristics map and diagenetic model map are all JPEG format image files.
Data reading mode: Excel file can be opened by Excel software in office software. JPEG format image file can be opened with the image software of windows

literatureList.titleEn: Partial Melts of Intermediate–Felsic Sources in a Wedged Thickened Crust: Insights from Granites in the Sulu Orogen
literatureList.referenceEn: Wu, H., He, Y., Li, S., Zhu, C., & Hou, Z. (2020). Partial melts of intermediate–felsic sources in a wedged thickened crust: insights from granites in the sulu orogen. Journal of Petrology.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used for analyzing the geochemical characteristics of Jurassic granites in an orogenic belt?
Example.Answer: A data collection method involves using X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF) to test major elements with precision within 2%, while trace elements are measured using inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) with precision within 5%. Additionally, zircon U-Pb isotopic ages are determined using secondary ion mass spectrometry (SIMS) to provide age data.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific characteristics and methods involved in collecting and analyzing Jurassic granite samples from orogenic belts?
Feature Specification.Answer: sampling information, age, elements, isotopes, hand specimen photos, microscopic photos, geochemical characteristics, diagenetic model diagrams, major elements accuracy within 2%, trace elements accuracy within 5%, zircon U-Pb isotopic dating

Quantification.Question: What is the precision level of major element measurements using X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy in a dataset related to Jurassic granites in the Sulu orogenic belt?

Definition.Question: What is the significance of using X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF) and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) for element testing in geochemical datasets?
Definition.Answer: In geochemical datasets related to the 苏鲁造山带侏罗纪花岗岩, X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF) is used for major element testing with a precision of within 2%, while inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) is employed for trace element testing with a precision of within 5%. These methods provide reliable and precise elemental composition data that are crucial for understanding the geochemical characteristics and post-collisional evolution of regions such as the 苏鲁造山带.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the geological processes in the Sulu Orogenic Belt by analyzing the age, elemental composition, and isotopic data in a dataset of Jurassic granites?
Interpretation.Answer: The dataset includes precise elemental and isotopic data, such as zircon U-Pb isotopic ages and elemental compositions obtained via XRF and ICP-MS. This information can provide insights into the post-collisional evolution of the Sulu Orogenic Belt by revealing patterns in the geochemical characteristics and the timing of rock formation processes.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences on data precision and insight generation when using X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF) and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) for geochemical analysis in orogenic belt studies?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF) for major element analysis and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) for trace elements in orogenic belt studies offers high precision, with XRF achieving precision within 2% and ICP-MS within 5%. This precision enhances the reliability of geochemical data, providing significant insights into the post-collisional evolution of the orogenic belt, as evidenced by the publication in the Journal of Petrology.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to collect detailed geochemical characteristics and isotopic data for Jurassic granites in the Sulu orogenic belt?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Collecting detailed geochemical characteristics and isotopic data for Jurassic granites in the Sulu orogenic belt is crucial because it provides significant insights into the post-collisional evolution of the orogenic belt. Such data, including zircon U-Pb isotopic ages and elemental compositions, help in understanding the processes and conditions that influenced granite formation during the Jurassic period. These insights are valuable for reconstructing the geological history and assessing the tectonic and magmatic activities in the region.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the instrumental and procedural steps involved in collecting and analyzing Jurassic granite samples from the Sulu Orogenic Belt to ensure accurate geochemical characterization?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data collection involves sampling Jurassic granite in the Sulu Orogenic Belt, followed by testing major elements using X-ray fluorescence (XRF) with an accuracy within 2%. Trace elements are analyzed using inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) with an accuracy within 5%. Additionally, zircon U-Pb isotopic ages are determined using secondary ion mass spectrometry (SIMS). The dataset includes sampling information, age, element and isotope data, hand specimen photos, micro-photos, geochemical characteristic diagrams, and diagenetic model diagrams.
